title: Which current candidate for the U.S. Senate will the Center for Responsive Politics list as having raised the most money this election cycle?
preds: Scott nearly equal. Thanks to @Adamren’s post

Whoops spoke too soon to @Prognosticating-Beek.  Beto is $69m and Scott is $68.7m not sure if that includes the $15m own donation. So flipping around from 99-1 to 1-99 
67 (6) from 36. 
Edit: seems to have jumped a massive amount (14.2) from 54.5mn at Oct21
I believe this is one of the most misforecasted questions on GJO
Beto is going to give us white Irishmen a bad rep if he doesn't share some of that campaign loot.
It is probably going to be O'Rourke but Scott can raise virtually unlimited funds from himself so he could just decide to drop another 10 million tomorrow.
I wonder how many Babies and Pets are named Beto now...that would be a good just for fun question - How many Baby birth certificates have Beto on then by this time next year.

Unless some PAC or billionaire throws a massive ad blitz it seems Beto will remain at top. Should have just gone with 99-1 on first bet. Perhaps Rick Scott will write own campaign a big check to smother the market with ads and block out opponent. 
43 (2 today) from 28 99-1-0-0-0 
Was 80-10-5-1-4 now 99-1-0-0-0  SunNov4th: 67 (6) from 36 99-1-0-0-0
Question ends by Nov6. Not much time for donations to close a 6 million dollar gap.

Conesensus is at 93% and two highest fundraisers are  Senate Candidates O'Rourke, Beto (D)
(Texas District S2)
current district Texas District 16	$60,773,550 Scott, Rick (R)
(Florida District S1)	$54,585,756 All other candidates are too far behind to close this massive gap.
Beto Obama!  Like a tide or gravity.

Well, be careful on opensecrets, I made an error, and didn't select '2018' and got lifetime raised by McCaskill as higher than Beto.  That threw off my last analysis. This clearly is a 2 horse race between Beto and Rick. The others are 0% Gave a Margin of error of 0.041 to be more like a poll,  as there good be some SuperPACs that give to Rick in the 11th hour. Earlier MoE of 0.021 was too generous. WIth 2 weeks to go, some million more could come in but unlikely. Results:
Beto chance to win = 0.74 Scott chance to win = 0.26 =========== R code below ================== scott<-54.58
beto<-60.77
mcaskl<-62.8
hugins<-26.2 total<-beto+scott
pct_beto<-beto/total
pct_scott<-scott/total Dem_poll<- pct_beto
GOP_poll<- pct_scott
Dem_poll
GOP_poll  undecided_perc<-1-Dem_poll-GOP_poll
MoE<- mean(.041)
undecided_correction<-undecided_perc/70
cat('undecided correction', undecided_correction)
poll_spread<-c(2, 2, 2, 0, 2)  #enter all the spreads here of past polls
poll_spread_avg<-mean(poll_spread)
poll_spread_sd<- sd(poll_spread)
poll_spread_correction<-poll_spread_sd/70
cat('Poll spread correction ...' , poll_spread_correction)
MoE_correction<-MoE*(1+undecided_correction+poll_spread_correction)
stdev<-MoE_correction
cat('MoE_corrected to: ', MoE_correction)
Dem_probability_to_win <- pnorm(.5,(Dem_poll+.5*undecided_perc),  stdev, lower.tail=F)
cat('Dem chance to win =', round(Dem_probability_to_win,2)) GOP_probability_to_win <- pnorm(.5,(GOP_poll+.5*undecided_perc), stdev, lower.tail=F)
cat('GOP chance to win =', round(GOP_probability_to_win,2))
GOP_probability_to_win
Loved by the left running against Cruz who is the most hated by liberals means lots of money going his way.

Used https://www.opensecrets.org to confirm the 4 listed are highest raised. Data good to 17OCT18.   Academically, Treating it as an election and the ratio of raised is the % poll amount.  Threw out lowest 2, Hugin, Scott. Then adjusted 3% to scott as rough compensation. Hugin was way behind. Assumed .021 for Margin of Error as it should be tighter due to finance disclosure than a poll. R code below
========================= scott<-54.5
beto<-60.7
mcaskl<-62.8
hugins<-26.2 total<-beto+mcaskl
pct_beto<-beto/total
pct_mcaskl<-mcaskl/total Dem_poll<- pct_beto
GOP_poll<- pct_mcaskl
Dem_poll
GOP_poll
undecided_perc<-1-Dem_poll-GOP_poll
MoE<- mean(.021)
undecided_correction<-undecided_perc/70
cat('undecided correction', undecided_correction)
poll_spread<-c(2, 2, 2, 0, 2)  #enter all the spreads here of past polls
poll_spread_avg<-mean(poll_spread)
poll_spread_sd<- sd(poll_spread)
poll_spread_correction<-poll_spread_sd/70
cat('Poll spread correction ...' , poll_spread_correction)
MoE_correction<-MoE*(1+undecided_correction+poll_spread_correction)
stdev<-MoE_correction
cat('MoE_corrected to: ', MoE_correction)
Dem_probability_to_win <- pnorm(.5,(Dem_poll+.5*undecided_perc),  stdev, lower.tail=F)
cat('Dem chance to win =', round(Dem_probability_to_win,2)) GOP_probability_to_win <- pnorm(.5,(GOP_poll+.5*undecided_perc), stdev, lower.tail=F)
cat('GOP chance to win =', round(GOP_probability_to_win,2))
